messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 52 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: GRID MINORS AND PRODUCTS

Paper Abstract: Abstract Motivated by recent developments regarding the product structure of planar graphs, we study relationships between treewidth, grid minors, and graph products. We show that the Cartesian product of any two connected nùëõn-vertex graphs contains an Œ©‚Äã(n)√óŒ©‚Äã(n)Œ©ùëõŒ©ùëõ\Omega(\sqrt{n})\times\Omega(\sqrt{n}) grid minor. This result is tight: The lexicographic product (which includes the Cartesian product as a subgraph) of a star and any nùëõn-vertex tree has no œâ‚Äã(n)√óœâ‚Äã(n)ùúîùëõùúîùëõ\omega(\sqrt{n})\times\omega(\sqrt{n}) grid minor.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 52 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 52"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Graph product structure for h‚Ñéh-framed graphs",
        "Nonserial dynamic programming",
        "Reduced bandwidth: a qualitative strengthening of twin-width in minor-closed classes (and beyond)",
        "Asymptotically optimal vertex ranking of planar graphs",
        "Some remarks on the Kronecker product of graphs",
        "The treewidth and pathwidth of hypercubes",
        "Polynomial bounds for the grid-minor theorem",
        "Towards tight(er) bounds for the excluded grid theorem",
        "The monadic second-order logic of graphs. I. Recognizable sets of finite graphs",
        "Subexponential parameterized algorithms on bounded-genus graphs and HùêªH-minor-free graphs",
        "Diameter and treewidth in minor-closed graph families, revisited",
        "Quickly deciding minor-closed parameters in general graphs",
        "Algorithmic graph minor theory: improved grid minor bounds and Wagner‚Äôs contraction",
        "Graph theory, vol. 173 of Graduate Texts in Mathematics",
        "Highly connected sets and the excluded grid theorem",
        "Improved product structure for graphs on surfaces",
        "Powers of planar graphs, product structure, and blocking partitions",
        "Improved bounds for centered colorings",
        "Adjacency labelling for planar graphs (and beyond)",
        "Planar graphs have bounded nonrepetitive chromatic number",
        "Clustered 3-colouring graphs of bounded degree",
        "The grid-minor theorem revisited",
        "Planar graphs have bounded queue-number",
        "Bounded-degree planar graphs do not have bounded-degree product structure",
        "Layered separators in minor-closed graph classes with applications",
        "Graph product structure for non-minor-closed classes",
        "On comparable box dimension",
        "Diameter and treewidth in minor-closed graph families",
        "Grid minors in damaged grids",
        "On the treewidth of Hanoi graphs",
        "Parameterized leaf power recognition via embedding into graph products",
        "Sparse universal graphs for planarity",
        "De summis serierum reciprocarum",
        "Excluded grid minors and efficient polynomial-time approximation schemes",
        "SùëÜS-functions for graphs",
        "Parameters tied to treewidth",
        "Structural properties of graph products",
        "Shallow minors, graph products and beyond planar graphs",
        "Product structure of graphs with an excluded minor",
        "Bounding twin-width for bounded-treewidth graphs, planar graphs, and bipartite graphs",
        "Linear min-max relation between the treewidth of an HùêªH-minor-free graph and its largest grid minor",
        "Lower bounds for treewidth of product graphs",
        "Twin-width of graphs on surfaces",
        "Tree-width and planar minors",
        "Almost exact minimum feedback vertex set in meshes and butterflies",
        "Graph minors. V. Excluding a planar graph",
        "Quickly excluding a planar graph",
        "Graph minors. III. Planar tree-width",
        "Graph searching and a min-max theorem for tree-width",
        "An improved planar graph product structure theorem",
        "Clique minors in Cartesian products of graphs",
        "Treewidth of cartesian products of highly connected graphs"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 52 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in GRID MINORS AND PRODUCTS, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
